double_jeopardy_round: A BOY NAMED SUE, ET AL.

(1, 1).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew reports from the Denver Mint.)  For its first 46 years, the United States Mint at Denver was an assay office, stemming from the discovery of this at Cherry Creek in 1858

(2, 1).clue: The AP's Alexander Zemlianichenko won a Pulitzer for his 1996 photo of this Russian president dancing at a rock concert

(3, 1).clue: A well-marbled steak is streaked with this substance

(5, 1).clue: Performers who have played this boss of Bond include Bernard Lee, Robert Brown, & most recently, Judi Dench

(1, 2).clue: It's the University of Colorado Campus founded in 1876, & we hear that its parties really "rock"

(2, 2).clue: This photographer famous for her Rolling Stone covers has been called the "portraitist of the rock generation"

(3, 2).clue: The government grades for beef include Select, Choice & this highest one

(5, 2).clue: Ian Fleming's 6th novel, this story about a fanatical "physician" bent on world domination was the 1st Bond film released

(6, 2).clue: Frank Sinatra was often described as this type of smooth-singing balladeer

(1, 3).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew appears in Colorado Springs, Colorado.)  Built into a Colorado mountain, this command complex of this 5-letter air defense organization sits on 1,000 lb. springs, to help it survive nuclear attack

(2, 3).clue: This American-born Dadaist was known for his "cameraless" pictures, which he called rayographs

(3, 3).clue: This "steak", a seasoned & broiled hamburger patty, is named for an American doctor, not a British city

(5, 3).clue: Call him Blond, James Blond; this star of 2006's "Casino Royale" is the first blond actor to play 007

(6, 3).clue: In this billiards game, players have 15 red balls to shoot as well as 6 balls of other colors

(1, 4).clue: If you know what this state's name means, you'll know that the "C" on its flag is this color

(2, 4).clue: This Californian's books include "My Camera in the National Parks" & "Parmelian Prints of the High Sierras"

(3, 4).clue: The cut of beef between the neck & shoulder blade has this masculine name

(5, 4).clue: A Bond girl in "Die Another Day", she won an Oscar for "Monster's Ball"

(6, 4).clue: It's the scientific study of animals

(1, 5).clue: The "Springs" in this city's name could be changed to "Strings, as it hosts the Strings in the Mountains Music Festival

(2, 5).clue: Best known as a writer of children's stories, he was also a fine photographer; Alice Liddell was a subject

(3, 5).clue: As its name indicates, Steak au Poivre is covered with this before cooking

(5, 5).clue: Author Ian Fleming wrote that James Bond looked a lot like this composer of "Stardust'

(6, 5).clue: This slang word meaning "scat!" or "leave quickly" comes from the Spanish for "let us go"

(1, 1).clue: To help the baby's nervous system develop, pregnant women need lots of the B vitamin known as this acid

(2, 1).clue: Many of the tracks on his 1977 release "Moody Blue" were recorded at Graceland

(3, 1).clue: This children's classic begins, "Chug, chug, chug.  Puff, puff, puff"

(4, 1).clue: Sportswriter Shirley Povich was this talk-show host's dad (& he wouldn't stop you from calling him Shirley)

(5, 1).clue: Influential Archduke Matthias went on to achieve this Imperial title in 1612 following his brother's death

(6, 1).clue: This term first appeared in print in 1971 & refers to the many electronics firms in Santa Clara County, California

(1, 2).clue: Seen here is one of the original tubes used by Roentgen at the time of his discovery of these

(2, 2).clue: "Grease" was second only to this Bee Gees release as the top soundtrack LP of the 1970s

(3, 2).clue: Antione de Saint-Exupery illustrated this fable about a boy visitor from another planet

(4, 2).clue: This actress has played a vice president, a chief justice, Homer Simpson's mom & Cruella de Vil

(5, 2).clue: Despite his epilepsy, Archduke Charles ably led Austrian forces to victory over this man in May 1809

(6, 2).clue: The reindeer-herding Nenets came up with this term for the hooded jacket they invented

(1, 3).clue: De Quervain disease, affecting a tendon at this joint, is found in those with repetitive jobs, as on assembly lines

(2, 3).clue: This rocker "comes alive" in a 1976 LP that included 2 Top 10 hits: "Show Me The Way" & "Do You Feel Like We Do"

(3, 3).clue: In this 1935 novel Laura & her family leave the big woods & go west in a covered wagon

(4, 3).clue: His "Trees" first appeared in Poetry Magazine in 1913

(5, 3).clue: In 1599 Archduke Albert married Isabella, the Infanta of this country, & together they ruled Belgium

(6, 3).clue: This phrase referring to rich or important people came from the part of the loaf given to honored guests

(1, 4).clue: Far away from Lyme, the lone star type of this parasite carries ehrlichiosis, a bacterial infection

(2, 4).clue: His 1978 album "52nd Street" was named for a NYC area famous for its jazz scene

(3, 4).clue: James Frey's tale of addiction & rehab; turns out it wasn't really nonfiction

(4, 4).clue: In 1910 Joyce Hall founded what would be this company; his autobiography is called "When You Care Enough"

(5, 4).clue: His resume includes Austrian Archduke & (tragically) Emperor of Mexico

(6, 4).clue: Anyone who pretends to hold opinions that he really doesn't share; it once was a Greek term for an actor

(1, 5).clue: In 2005 a French team performed the first of these procedures--some fear the recipient will look just like the donor

(2, 5).clue: "I Feel The Earth Move" is the first track on this 1971 Carole King album

(3, 5).clue: Uncle Tom is devoted to the angelic daughter of his owner, who's called this

(4, 5).clue: In 1945 he wrote "Brideshead Revisited"--& FYI, the "e" that starts his 1st name is pronounced "ee", not "eh"

(5, 5).clue: A member of this family, Archduke Otto is heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne but renounced his claim

(6, 5).clue: This plant's name is derived from the Greek for "dolphin" because a part of it resembles a dolphin

(0, 0).clue: In 2006 this Milwaukee-based co. announced its new stock symbol, "HOG", at a gathering in Sturgis, S.D.
